docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Melanie Klein needed a vaccination recently to attend community college, she had few affordable options. She is a German citizen working as a live-in nanny for a Westchester family and says she has only emergency health coverage. Including the physical examination she would need as a prelude to the shot, she said, ''I was told it would cost about $300.''

headline.main: 'The Nurse Practitioner Will See You Now'

docs.abstract: Article on MinuteClinic in Larchmont, NY, one of several companies that have started offering health care in more than two dozen of New York metropolitan region's drugstores and supermarkets; clinics, staffed by nurse practitioners, say they are low-cost answer for minor health problems for uninsured and those who want after-hours or speedy care; critics say clinics could undermine importance of doctor-patient relationships, follow-up care will be lacking and some insurers do not cover visits

docs.lead_paragraph: Since handing over day-to-day control of his family's auto company to a new chief executive, Alan R. Mulally, last fall, William Clay Ford Jr. has rarely been seen in public. But last week he joined the C.E.O.'s of Detroit's other automakers to support President Bush's new health care initiative at a luncheon with Michael O. Leavitt, the secretary of health and human services. Mr. Ford, now executive chairman of the Ford Motor Company, might have used the gathering of so many wealthy Michiganders to pass out some brochures on his former home in Ann Arbor, Mich., which is now listed for sale. The 6,500-square-foot, contemporary home on 17 acres along the Huron River is priced at $3.95 million.

headline.main: A Motivated Seller In the Motor City

docs.abstract: Former Ford chief executive William Clay Ford Jr joins chief executives of Detroit's other automakers to support Pres Bush's new health care initiative at luncheon with Health and Human Services Sec Michael Leavitt (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The lower house of Parliament approved a long-awaited deal for new financing of the national health care system, which is under strain from the rising cost of care, an aging population and high unemployment. The legislation, which is expected to be adopted by the upper house, requires everyone in Germany to have health insurance by 2009, when a state-run central fund will pool contributions and distribute money to insurers. The fund is intended to force inefficient health insurers to cut costs.

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s plan to freeze Medicaid payments at current levels for hospitals and nursing homes looks like a responsible way to free up money for a huge increase in state aid for education and other proposals.

docs.lead_paragraph: The lower house of Parliament approved a long-awaited deal for new financing of the national health care system, which is under strain from the rising cost of care, an aging population and high unemployment. The legislation, which is expected to be adopted by the upper house, requires everyone in Germany to have health insurance by 2009, when a state-run central fund will pool contributions and distribute money to insurers. The fund is intended to force inefficient health insurers to cut costs. VICTOR HOMOLA

docs.lead_paragraph: Most of the Democratic field is in Washington today for the Democratic National Committee's winter meeting. See the "On Deck" section below for the list of who's speaking today and Saturday. You'll notice that all of the speakers have already have declared their candidacy or formed an exploratory committee except Gen. Wesley Clark. Hmmm.
